Def.Name: Tatarian Maple
Def.Description: Spreading shrub or small tree growing to 13' - 40' tall, with a short trunk up to 8" - 20" diameter and slender branches.
Def.Leaves: Opposite and simple, broadly ovate, 1 3/4" - 4" long and 1" - 2 3/4" broad, unlobed or with three or five shallow lobes, and matt green above; the leaf margin is coarsely and irregularly toothed; the leaf petiole is slender, often pink-tinged, 3/4" - 2" long.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Paired reddish samara, 3/8" - 7/16" long with a 13/16" - 1 3/16" wing, maturing in late summer to early autumn.
Def.Bark: Thin, pale brown, and smooth at first but becoming shallowly fissured on old plants.
Def.Range: Hardy to zone 3a. Native to central and southeastern Europe and southwestern Asia, from Austria east to southwestern Russia and the Caucasus, and south to Turkey.
Def.Remarks: The species is named after the Tatar peoples of southern Russia; the tree's name is similarly commonly also spelled "Tartar" in English.
